result.heading: BEHIND THE WORLD OF DONUTS -- DAY

direction.raw_text: . BEHIND THE WORLD OF DONUTS -- DAY Moments later. He comes walking up a small alley and sits to drink his beer. He begins to relax. This is his quality private time. Then he hears something and looks up. He peeks up over the edge of some junked kitchen appliances and sees... Two teenage kids -- Warren and Amy -- smoking crack and having sex. Simon looks on, intrigued, as Warren smokes, then...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Amy takes the pipe and smokes as he feels her up. Simon is fascinated. He drinks and looks on as... Amy grins up foolishly at Warren and lowers the pipe. The boy undoes his belt and hikes up the girl's skirt. Simon can't believe this. He looks around to see if the coast is clear, then returns just in time to see... Warren takes Amy by the waist and enter her. The pipe falls from the young girl's hand. Warren throws his head back and grinds himself into her. Simon's mouth falls open in awe. But Amy tosses her head back to the side and sees... The amazed garbage man; caught. Amy starts screaming insanely. Simon runs for his life. Amy and Warren throw rocks and bottles at him as they chase him away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE GRIM HOUSE -- DAY Moments later. Simon runs up and throws open the screen door. He stands there in the doorway catching his breath. His sister, Fay, is at the kitchen table watching a small portable TV while their mother, Mary, sits a few feet away in the living-room watching another TV tuned to a different channel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary is a manic-depressive, still in her bathrobe at six in the evening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fay holds her head in her hands and sighs. She glares at her brother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon sits at the table and Fay slams down before him a bowl of some sort of gruel. He hesitates, then lifts his spoon. Supper is horrible and he screws up his face in disgust. Fay gives him a sideways glance and he leans back down over the bowl and eats some more. Pushing the bowl away gently, he reaches out for the container of milk on the table and drinks straight from it. He suddenly jumps back and spits out sour milk all over the table. The container drops to the floor and thick globs of cheese roll out. He stands back against the fridge, holding his stomach while... Fay and Mary look on in disgust.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to Simon) Where the hell have you been? (to Mary) Mom, come on and eat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know why you cooked! I don't know why you bother!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . THE GRIM HOUSE -- DAY Moments later. Simon crosses the lawn and sits on the curb outside his house. He stares at the ground before him as he holds his stomach and spits, sickened. He looks up, though, and sees... A little seven-year-old girl -- Pearl age seven -- standing there in the street watching him. Simon tries to smile at her. But she throws a rock at him and hits him in the head. He falls forward, hurt, as the little girl runs away. Lowering his hand, he sees he's bleeding. Desperate, lonely and ill, he drags his bloodied fingers across the coarse pavement. Fay slams out of the side door of the house in a tight-fitting dress and stands on the lawn, applying lipstick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fay snaps shut her compact, straightens her skirt and sighs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon loses track of what he is hearing and relaxes. He looks back at his sister. Fay fluffs out her hair and walks off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon watches her go, but is still drawn to something he seems to hear up the street in the other direction. He cocks his head, sits perfectly still and listens. He hears it now. We do, too. Footsteps. Big ones. Like a giant somewhere in the distance. The neighborhood trembles. Titles begin. Simon tries to figure out where it's coming from; the sky, the house, the highway at the end of his block... Finally, he focuses on... The blacktop right before him, smeared with his own blood. Music starts. He kneels out slowly into the street and stares at the pavement. He stretches out his hand and places it flat on the road. The pounding is louder now, becoming the beat of the music over the scene. Simon lowers his face to the pavement, closes his eyes and... Puts his ear right down against the road. He hears... The steady tread of somebody very much larger than life. Kneeling forward, with his ear to the ground, Simon opens his eyes and sees... A man approaching. The music swells up full. Simon lifts his head slowly from the road, looking off in wonder at... This stranger coming towards him; an oddly handsome freak striding over the crest of the distant intersection with a windswept mane, two over-stuffed suitcases and a crumpled tie fluttering back over his broad but crooked shoulders. Simon rises till he's kneeling up straight in the road. Henry Fool finally reaches him and stops. Titles finish. Simon says nothing and watches as Henry looks off at the house. Satisfied, but wary, Henry Fool looks around the neighborhood and then down at Simon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He tosses the suitcases down in front of Simon and walks off towards his new home.
direction.name: direction

result.ToD: BACK OF THE GRIM HOUSE -- DAY
result.heading: BACK OF THE GRIM HOUSE -- DAY

direction.raw_text: . BACK OF THE GRIM HOUSE -- DAY Henry comes around behind the house and finds the door to his basement apartment. He approaches. Simon follows, carrying the suitcases.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HENRY'S APARTMENT -- DAY Moments later. The door is wrenched open and Henry is hit square in the jaw by a decade of dank airless gloom. He coughs. Entering, he finds a few old wooden chairs littering the main room. He inspects the old wood stove, then takes a chair and smashes it. He tosses the wood in the stove. Simon looks on, amazed. Henry lights a fire with unusually quick results, then stands back and looks at Simon.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Where you gotta go to get a six-pack of beer around here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . WORLD OF DONUTS -- DAY This is a convenience store with a number of tables at which to eat donuts. Warren is shoplifting while Amy terrorizes Gnoc Deng, the Vietnamese cashier, who stares out at them from behind the safety of the counter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Amy looks back at Gnoc, snarls, then follows the cashier's gaze to the door. Simon enters. Clutching Henry's cash, he stops dead in his tracks when he sees... Warren and Amy. He steps forward and approaches the beer cooler. Warren and Amy hover around, just out of reach, like a couple of vampires. Dragging a six-pack out of the cooler, Simon crosses to the counter. Warren and Amy hang back, silent and threatening. Gnoc rings up the purchase and glances over at... Amy, staring a hole into the side of Simon's skull. Gnoc hands Simon back his change and he makes for the door, but... Warren shoves himself between it and Simon. Simon freezes. Warren is expressionless. Simon looks back at Amy. She turns away, reaches up under her skirt, jerks down her panties, then leans forward on to the counter. Leering back over her shoulder, she hisses...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon is nonplussed. Gnoc presses a button on the wall that sets... A red light flashing above the stockroom door. Warren grabs Simon by the neck and drags him over to Amy's bare behind. Amy laughs as Simon is forced to his knees and has his face shoved up right into the crack of her ass. But then... Simon throws up all over her. Warren falls back in disgust. Gnoc covers her face with her hands. Amy looks around at herself, realizes, and starts screaming bloody murder. Simon falls back on to the floor, clutching his stomach, as Amy staggers around with her vomit-strewn underwear down around her ankles. Then Gnoc's father, Mr Deng, appears at the stockroom door holding a shovel and ready to fight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Deng comes running at them and Warren drags Amy from the store. Simon crawls out of the way as the old man throws open the door to the parking lot and screams at the retreating delinquents...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Having scared them off, he comes back in and starts screaming at Simon.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (in Vietnamese) Stay the hell out of my store, you good-for-nothing punks!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look at this! What's going on here? Simon, get up off the floor! Is this beer paid for?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . HENRY'S APARTMENT -- NIGHT Later. Simon splashes water over his face at the kitchen sink, then watches as Henry unpacks one of his suitcases. It is filled with dozens of old, worn notebooks. Henry stacks them on the mantelpiece over the fireplace; the fire is now crackling and bright. Simon steps over and looks at... The name tag on the other suitcase: 'Henry Fool'.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon looks over and sees... Henry's silhouette against the fire. He steps forward into the light and grabs a beer from the six-pack on the floor. He hands one to Simon. Simon takes it and stares at it a moment before raising his eyes to Henry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He winks at Simon, then struts around the room, hugely impressed with himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon comes away from the fire, watching him carefully. Henry stands in a dim corner across the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry pauses, looks aside, drinks, then grins demoniacally. He steps forward and comes face to face with Simon. He lifts his finger and points to... Simon's name stitched upon the breast of his work shirt. Realizing this, Simon moves off and thinks. Henry throws more wood on the fire, glancing back over his shoulder, laughing mischievously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He tries to articulate what he thinks he feels but winds up gesticulating curiously with his hands. This finally dissolves into a dumb stare into empty space.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon looks at him. Henry stands and grabs a notebook from off the mantelpiece. He tears out a few pages and shoves them in his pocket. He hands the now fresh writing tablet to Simon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He searches his pockets and finds a pencil.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon hesitates, then accepts the gifts. Henry goes for another beer while his new friend studies the dozens of notebooks on the mantelpiece.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry drinks and looks down into the raging fire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He smokes. Simon is impressed. They hear a bottle smash outside in the street and Henry goes to the window. They're throwing bottles at the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon jumps up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry stops. Simon looks away and sits back down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is ashamed of himself. Henry sees this and settles down. He considers his new friend with genuine care as he gets himself a new cigarette. He lights up, thinks, then grabs another chair and sits close by Simon. They sit there in silence a while, then...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry stares into the flames and falls silent. Simon is riveted. He leans forward, on the edge of his seat...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (off-screen) Centuries ago it had an 'e' at the end.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I go where I will and I do what I must. (stops, drinks) That's why I'm in trouble. I'm sort've what you might call... 'in exile'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (stopping) An honest man is always in trouble, Simon. Remember that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How do you know my name?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pauses) Well... I'll take your word for that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (explaining) People. I mean. They think. You know. Because.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...this. Keep them with you at all times. You ever feel like you got something to say and you can't get it out, stop and write it down. OK?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (proudly, returning) This? This is my life's work. My memoirs. My 'Confession'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (wistfully) I've been bad. Repeatedly. (shrugs and steps away) But why brag? The details of my exploits are only a pretext for a far more expansive consideration of general truths. (contemplating the notebooks) What is this? It's a philosophy. A poetics. A politics, if you will. A literature of protest. A novel of ideas. A pornographic magazine of truly comic-book proportions. It is, in the end, whatever the hell I want it to be. And when I'm through with it, it's gunna blow a hole this wide straight through the world's own idea of itself!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (throwing down his cigarette) Come on, let's go break their arms!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Once. I forget where I was. Central America maybe. Somewhere hot. Stupid job. Bad pay. Dangerous location and water so foul the natives wouldn't even piss in it. This crowd of drunken motherfuckers hired by the local drug cartel shows up at my hotel room and threatens to tear me limb from limb. And I say, listen, hombres, OK, you've got me outnumbered four to one and you're gunna kill me here tonight and not a soul in this dimly lit world is ever gunna notice I'm gone. Fine. But one of you... one of you... one of you is gunna have his eye torn out. Period. Silence. I repeat myself. One of you poor, underpaid jerks is gunna have an eye ripped out of its socket. I promise. It's a small thing, perhaps, all things considered. But I will succeed. Because it's the only thing I have left to do in this world. So why don't you just take a good look at one another one last time and think it over for a few minutes more. (smokes, waits) They sober up a little, look at their shoes in confusion, then step out into the hall to talk among themselves.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (winking) Well, here I am, still, after all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . UPSTAIRS -- NIGHT Later that night. Simon climbs the stairs and stops when he hears raunchy sex from his sister's room. He stands outside her door and listens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon looks up the hall and sees his mother in her room, sitting on the edge of her bed, smoking. He approaches and stands in her doorway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon says nothing. He looks down at his feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now she says nothing. She smokes and looks away. Simon steps into the bathroom and gets her medication. He runs a glass of water and brings it in to her. She swallows the pills and washes them back with water.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks away, unconcerned and cynical.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She throws the blanket over herself and turns off the light. Simon stands there in the dark.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (off) Did you throw up all over some girl?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They were throwing bottles at the house.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (gesturing to Fay's room) She's got some ex-con in there she met at the bar. Tattoos all over himself and a big red bloated nose.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You want me to tell her to be quiet?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's the use? She might as well get it while she can. She's not always gunna have the ass she has now, you know. That's just how life is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . THE GRIM HOUSE KITCHEN -- NIGHT Moments later. Simon comes downstairs into the quiet, dark kitchen and sits at the table. He listens to the traffic on the highway and stares off into space. Finally, he takes the notebook Henry gave him from his pocket and places it before him. But then he just gazes off into the dim living-room and scratches his head. Returning his attention to the notebook, he digs down into his pocket and retrieves his short stub of pencil. He opens the notebook and carefully flattens back the cover. Lifting the pencil, he pauses and stares at the blank page. Then, after more intense hesitation, he brings the pencil's dull tip to the very top left edge of the page and begins writing in a slow, laborious hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE GRIM HOUSE KITCHEN -- DAY The next morning. Henry barges in the kitchen door with two containers of coffee and some jelly donuts. Simon jumps up from where he sits asleep over his notebook at the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon rubs the sleep from his eyes, blinks, disoriented and reaches for his wallet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He lifts up Simon's notebook.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon hesitates, shyly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He gives up, sighs and gazes at the floor. Henry flips through the book, impressed. It is full from cover to cover, every page dense with Simon's cryptic scrawl. Henry frowns, intrigued. Then...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon looks up, terrified. But his friend puts him at ease.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Good morning, Simon! Glorious day, huh? Here, have a donut. Can you lend me twenty dollars?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks. Where's the library in the scruffy little burgh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (handing him cash) Down the highway about a mile and a half and then make a left.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Excellent! I'm polishing up the final chapters of my 'Confession' and I need a reasonably well-stocked reference section.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought. Um. I was. I wanted to. Maybe.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . JUNK YARD -- DAY Later that day. Simon finds a number of volumes of the classics while crushing garbage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BEHIND WORLD OF DONUTS -- DAY That evening. Simon sits with his evening beer and his new collection of soiled classics. He cracks open a volume of Shakespeare and tries to read. It's an obvious struggle. He puts it aside and lifts up Wordsworth, studying its cover and the texture of the pages. A page flutters away and he climbs down to the edge of a greasy puddle to retrieve it. It's now wet and torn, so he flattens it out on the concrete and tries to fit it back into the book. He reads a little, furrowing his brow, then drinks. He bites his lip and tries again. He sits back, exhausted and thinks. He hears a twig snap and looks back over his shoulder to see... Amy throws a bottle at his head. Smash!!!! He falls to the ground, blood streaming down his neck. Warren runs over and grabs him by the shirt, lifting him out of the puddle and smacking him in the head. Amy runs forward and waits with a rolled-up newspaper which she sets aflame with her lighter. Warren punches Simon in the stomach and throws him to the ground, then unzips his fly and pisses on him. Amy watches, giggling excitedly, waving the flaming torch. Simon crawls away and grabs hold of an old section of fence, while Warren zips up and grabs the fire from Amy. Simon pulls himself to his knees, rests his face against the rusted fence and gasps for breath. Warren waves the flaming torch in his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Amy comes nearer with a can of gasoline. Simon pulls himself to his feet as she splashes him with fuel. Warren is waving the torch deliriously above his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Warren stops. Amy steps back and lowers the gas can. Simon turns with effort to face them, adjusts his glasses and continues...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Warren watches him blankly, then is burned by the torch which is too hot to handle. He drops it. Amy giggles, then stops, excited, but confused. Simon grips the rusted chainlink so that it cuts into his hands and stares straight at Warren.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Warren is transfixed. He shivers and looks at Amy, who steps back, scared, and puts down the gas can. She turns and walks away. Warren looks back at Simon, troubled. He hangs there still, glaring at him. Further away, Warren rejoins Amy and stares at his hands. Amy looks ill.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (weakly, unheard) One of you is gunna lose an eye.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (screaming) One of you is gunna lose an eye!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can set me on fire. But one of you is gunna have an eye torn out of your head. I promise.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . WORLD OF DONUTS -- DAY Henry is at one of the tables, correcting the spelling in Simon's notebook, when he looks up and sees... Simon stumble in, beaten and bruised, dropping his classics to the floor. Henry and Mr Deng rush over to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He passes out. Henry looks at Mr Deng.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry nods, agreeing, then lifts Simon off the floor. Mr Deng holds the door open as Henry carries his friend out into the parking lot. Meanwhile, Gnoc gathers up the classics from the floor and places them beside Simon's notebook, where it still sits open on the table. She looks at it, then reads. She lifts it off the table and reads further, immediately and deeply engrossed. Mr Deng watches as Henry departs with Simon, then comes back into the store and stops, startled, when he sees... Gnoc sitting there, staring off into space, the notebook open in her hands before her, singing quietly.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (scared) Simon! Who did this to you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was gunna tear out their eyes. I knew I could do it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I told them. Like you said. I told them. And I knew I could do it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You should take him home. He smells like a toilet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . THE GRIM HOUSE -- DAY Twenty minutes later. Fay is in the bathroom helping Simon out of his clothes, trying to clean his wounds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry is at the kitchen table with Mary. She watches him suspiciously. He lets her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She watches him as he walks around the room, browsing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He stops and lifts a small framed photo of a soldier off the piano.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Violated somehow, she gets up and snatches it out of his hands. She puts it in a drawer and cringes as Henry plays one note on the piano.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He fixes her with a steady, knowing stare which causes her to gather the collar of her bathrobe up around her neck. She steps back, exposed, when there's a knock at the door. They look over to see... Mr Deng enter with the notebook.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry comes over, takes the notebook from him and shoves it in his pocket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Meanwhile, back in the bathroom...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She storms out to the top of the stairs, cocks her hip and whines...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon reaches out and slams the bathroom door. Fay looks from the bathroom door down the stairs to Mary. Mary, her nerves rattled, glances over at Mr Deng, who turns and leaves the house. Henry lights a fresh cigarette, loosens his tie and heads upstairs.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (calling) Shit, Mom, we gotta get him to a hospital!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This kinda thing has happened before.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nods to Mary, then) Mr Fool, what is this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course I'm sure. I corrected the spelling myself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, well, you know -- that's what poetry does.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But she has never spoken in her life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (fed up) Fine! You do it, Simon! I don't care!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mom! Simon's got a broken rib, his shoulder's dislocated or something, and he won't let me disinfect the gash in his head!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fay, just take him to the hospital, will ya!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (stamping her foot) But he won't go!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (screaming) Simon Grim, you go to the hospital with Fay right now, do hear me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . THE GRIM HOUSE BATHROOM -- DAY A moment later. Henry throws open the door and enters. He steps over Simon, who is on the floor, folded up against the toilet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry sits on the edge of the bathtub and takes the notebook from his pocket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon just looks at him, not certain what he means.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He scratches his chin and smokes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon just stares at him, overwhelmed. Henry drops the notebook on the floor and points at it with his cigarette.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon just blinks, looks away and wonders.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon coughs and Henry leans back and smokes.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What the hell were you trying to do when you wrote this thing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, you know you wrote it in a kind of iambic pentameter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look, in my opinion, this is pretty powerful stuff. Though your spelling is Neanderthal, and your reasoning a little naive, your instincts are profound. But the whole thing needs to be given a more cohesive shape. It can be expanded. Followed through. Unified. (smokes, then) You see what I'm getting at?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you willing to commit yourself to this? To really work on it? To give it its due? In the face of adversity and discouragement? To rise to the challenge you yourself have set?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And don't gimme that wonderstruck 'I'm-only-a-humble-garbage-man' bullshit, either.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . THE GRIM HOUSE UPSTAIRS -- NIGHT An hour later. Fay cringes outside Simon's room as Henry goes about setting her brother's arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon does.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pauses, then leans back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon nods and stares at the ceiling. Henry hands him a towel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon bites down on the towel and grips the edge of the bed with his free hand. Henry sits on his legs and gently raises the broken arm. Outside the door, Fay bites her knuckles. Further down the hall, Mary listens from her bedroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon nods. Henry grabs hold of the arm, swallows and braces himself. Simon waits, then Henry tugs the arm straight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fay turns and runs down the stairs. Mary backs away into her room and shuts the door.

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. Now shut up and lie back.

dialogue.raw_text: (looking) It's blood. From your head. Lie back. Shove that in your mouth and hold on to something.

direction.raw_text: . THE GRIM HOUSE KITCHEN -- NIGHT Later that night. Henry comes downstairs and stops, tired. Fay is sitting at the table with a bottle of gin and two glasses. She has dolled herself up a little and Henry likes what he sees. He looks her over and she smiles. He sits. She pours. They drink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They drink again in silence. He lights her cigarette and they watch each other closely. Finally, Fay leans on the table and twirls a strand of her hair between her fingers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He drinks and studies her. She presents her profile. Finally, he leans back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fay jumps up, furious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She grabs her bag and storms out of the house. Henry watches her go, then chuckles deviously and splashes himself another drink.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: So, do you have, like, you know, a girlfriend, Henry?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I look young for my age, don't I?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How old do you think I am?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But how... I mean, do I look more like twenty, or... you know, thirty?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Listen, you geek, after a couple of drinks plenty of people mistake me for eighteen!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . WORLD OF DONUTS -- DAY Next morning. A thirty-year-old cocktail waitress named Vicky walks up and stops when she sees... Warren, sitting back against the side of World of Donuts, smoking a joint and thinking about his future. She sighs and approaches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Unruffled, she hands him a flyer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He tokes deeply, then...

direction.raw_text: Vicky sighs, troubled. She adjusts her waitress uniform and looks mildly offended.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Warren gets up, too.

direction.raw_text: Vicky is hard-pressed. She wants to believe him, but knows better. She thinks about it while... Henry passes by and approaches the store.

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Warren, are you a registered voter?

dialogue.raw_text: (reading) 'Saving America From Itself.' What the fuck is this?

dialogue.raw_text: It's everything you need to know about the upcoming elections and congressman Owen Feer and all the really good things he wants to do for our country.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He wants to win back this country for us Americans, Warren, and restore some kind of cultural-moral standard to our way of life.

dialogue.raw_text: What time's your kid go off to school?

dialogue.raw_text: How about I come over and visit you later?

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I don't know, Warren. I mean...

dialogue.raw_text: Come on. I mean it. I'm trying to change.

direction.raw_text: . WORLD OF DONUTS -- DAY Same time. Henry enters and takes Simon's notebook from his pocket. He flips through a few pages and selects one in particular. He tears it out of the book and tapes it up beside the register so customers can read it. He winks at Gnoc. She smiles shyly and makes him a coffee. He takes it and moves off to a table just as... Vicky enters. She starts accumulating groceries, placing them on the counter one item at a time. Henry settles down and watches as... Vicky returns to the counter with a bottle of orange juice and notices the poem. She reads, holding the orange juice out to her side. Gnoc starts to ring up the other purchases as her father comes up behind her, busying himself with an inventory of the cigarettes. Vicky's lip starts to tremble as she reads, a horrified expression clouding her face. Finally... Smash!!!! She drops the bottle of orange juice and stands back. Mr Deng and Gnoc jump back, alarmed. Henry tilts his head and pays close attention.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Deng looks from her to the poem and then over at Henry. Henry urges the man to stand up for himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She grabs her things and leaves. Mr Deng holds his head and looks over at Henry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Deng has no idea. He sits, worried, as Gnoc comes out from behind the counter and begins mopping up the mess.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (screaming at Mr Deng) How dare you put something like this up where anyone can see it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's pornography! The product of a diseased mind! You oughta be ashamed of yourself, Mr Deng!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pauses, confused) It's disgusting! There oughta be a law or something!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (winking) There's no accounting for taste, is there, Mr Deng?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Later. Henry is at the kitchen table with Simon, working on the poem. Simon is bandaged up, his arm in a sling, black eyes, etc.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry lifts up one of Simon's newly acquired classics...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon looks past him and Henry follows his gaze to find... Mary standing at the foot of the stairs, listening to them. She says nothing. She looks Henry up and down, then shakes her head disdainfully and grunts. She throws herself on the couch and turns on the TV, casting acid glances over at the kitchen.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: See, Simon, there are three kinds of there. There's 'There'. T-H-E-R-E. There are the donuts. Then there's T- H-E-I-R; which is the possessive. It is their donut. Then, finally, there's 'they're'. T-H-E-Y-'-R-E. A contraction, meaning they are. They're the donut people. Get it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And look, if you're gunna read Wordsworth you've gotta get a more up-to-date edition. This odoriferous tome you're so attached to doesn't even have all fourteen books of the Prelude. And you need notes. Commentary. I'll go to the library and find you the best edition they have.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you, but that's OK. I'll stop there on my way back from work. Well, yes, maybe not today, but, you know, tomorrow, probably.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You need time to write, Simon. To study. To reflect.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We all have to make sacrifices. A vocation like ours, Simon, is not a nine to five thing. You can't put a fence around a man's soul. We think and feel where and when we can think and feel. We are the servants of our muse and we toil where she commands.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Moments later. Henry and Simon come outside...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry wanders out to the road, checking his wallet, then...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon looks off, thinks it over and slowly nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pulls the tiny piece of crumpled advice out from one of his pockets and shows it to Simon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hurries away around the corner. Simon walks back to the house and stops when he sees... A plain-clothes policeman, Officer Bunuel, drive up and park before the house. Simon spies as the man gets out of his car and knocks on Henry's door. He, of course, gets no answer.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (thinking, then) I guess it means it's not her fault.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Out there. You know, into the world. Where ever.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (reciting) 'Opportunity will step away and make room for a man to pass it by.'
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. I found it in a fortune cookie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. Not yet. Soon. We'll see.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (puffing himself up) Well, you know, Simon, a piece of work like this, it's... A vocation like ours... You can't put a fence around a man's soul. What I'm trying to achieve, it's... Well, it takes a lifetime really. It's a life's work. (looking around) But soon. Don't worry. I'd appreciate your feedback. I gotta go. See ya.

direction.raw_text: . THE GRIM HOUSE KITCHEN -- DAY Later that day. Simon works on his poem at the kitchen table while Fay flips through a magazine and watches TV. Mary, lying on the couch in her bathrobe, watches her own TV. The cacophony is augmented by the rattling dishwasher and the trucks rumbling by on the highway outside. Mary looks over at her son, suspicious, and leans off the couch.

direction.raw_text: He carefully finishes writing a word, then looks up and pauses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary looks at Fay, who looks up from her magazine and considers her brother. Then they break out laughing. Simon looks on. They laugh and laugh and laugh...

dialogue.raw_text: What are you doing there, Simon?

Amy and three kids are grouped around the register, reading the page Henry taped up earlier. As they read, Amy glances anxiously back at Simon. They finish reading and stand back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Amy nods 'Yes', then leads them towards Simon. Simon scribbles away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks up, sees her, panics and slides away on the seat. Amy looks down and bites her lip, contrite. She sighs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon looks around at them all, threatened.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon fumbles with his pencil, ill at ease and self-conscious. Then, to get rid of them, he nods his consent.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: So what? It ain't so great.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Uhm. Look, ah... I'm the editor of the high school newspaper now and...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: One of the editors, and we...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ... wanted to know if we could print your poem in this month's issue.

direction.raw_text: . THE GRIM HOUSE -- DAY That evening. Fay comes downstairs in only a towel and wet hair. She switches on the TV and looks for cigarettes. She finds Mary's pills on the table and remembers to ask...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary is lying on the couch. She drags her eyes from the TV and glances lazily at Fay, then back to the TV.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She sits at the kitchen table and lifts her magazine. Henry shows up at the kitchen door with a pile of library books. His eyes brighten when he sees... Fay sitting there wearing only her towel. He knocks. She looks back over her shoulder and sees him.

direction.raw_text: She turns away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He comes in and stacks the books near the sink. Fay pretends to ignore him, but rakes her fingers through her wet hair anyway, to show more shoulder. This is not lost on Henry, who tarries and leans back against the counter, salivating. Fay flips through her magazine and Henry steps closer and leans against the fridge. She casts a bored glance in his direction, then returns her attention to the TV. She senses him step aside and follows his movements without turning. Suddenly his hand appears from behind her and gently strokes her hair. She freezes, waits, wonders... He leans his face down beside her. She looks at him. He looks at her, then down to... Her bare legs crossed before her on the kitchen chair. His hand moves down and slides itself deep in between her things. Her mouth drops open. He looks back up at her. He grins. Fay jumps up and away, breathlessly clutching the towel around herself. Henry casts a glance over her body, throws his hair back out of his face and shivers with lust. Fay steps back and grabs hold of the staircase banister, making an unconvincing gesture of injured pride. Henry comes closer and she steps backwards up the stairs. He stops, loosens his tie, holding her with his gaze. She readjusts her towel, throws back her wet hair, sighs defiantly, then sashays into her room, leaving the door ajar. Henry waits there at the foot of the stairs, reaches down, grabs his crotch and repositions his hard-on. He takes a step up the stairs, then stops. He looks over to the couch and sees... Mary, lying there, sedately amazed. He pauses, then grins. Mary blinks and smiles sleepily.

dialogue.raw_text: I've got these books for Simon.

dialogue.raw_text: Well, leave 'em there on the counter, then.

direction.raw_text: . WORLD OF DONUTS -- DAY Same time. Simon sits back from his writing and rubs his neck. Putting down his pencil, he looks up and sees... Warren enter the store and grab a beer from the cooler. Seeing Simon, he waves and approaches.

direction.raw_text: Simon hesitates, but then nods uncertainly. Warren hands him a flyer. This year when you go to the polls, I want you to consider Congressman Owen Feer. He wants to restore America to its position of unmatched wealth, power and opportunity; to revitalize American civilization and lead the human race to even greater levels of freedom, prosperity and security! He's a good man. He steps over to the register and pays for his beer. Mr Deng glares at him, distrustfully. Warren stops on his way out and snarls at the old man...

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Simon, you a registered voter?

She sees no one in the kitchen, then looks in the living- room and stops. She goes white, her mouth falling open in horror. Henry and Mary are screwing one another on the couch. Sloppy, impassioned, brute sex.

Fay is crushed. She breaks out in tears and runs upstairs. Henry catches his breath and starts after her, but stops, uncertain and confused.

direction.raw_text: He drinks, burps, then slams down the can. He glances over at Tim who is still looking on.

direction.raw_text: Tim hesitates, but then obeys. He gets up and leaves. Henry returns to Simon.

direction.raw_text: Simon blinks. Henry adds...

direction.raw_text: Simon is deeply confused. He looks ill. He stands and takes a few steps away, staring at the floor.

direction.raw_text: Simon stops and looks at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon pauses, then comes closer to Henry and stops.

direction.raw_text: Henry jumps up, strides around the store and speaks at the top of his voice.

direction.raw_text: He walks to the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He strides out of the store. Simon stands there, stunned and looks at Mr Deng as the old man wipes off the table with a wet rag.

dialogue.raw_text: Listen. I know a man. He's a big shot in the publishing business. Angus James. Smart, adventurous and tons of integrity. When this thing is ready, I'll recommend he reads it. He'll respect my opinion.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A man was here today looking for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know. He drove by the house a few times.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why do they torment me like this? Why? They're like a bunch of fucking mosquitoes!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do they want from you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They want to suffocate me, Simon! They wanna extinguish me like a flame!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're afraid, that's why! They're afraid of what I might do! What I might say! Think! They're afraid of my ideas!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You and I are alike in this way, Simon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're outsiders. We think and feel too much and too deeply. And the world can't handle that. Our mere existence is a threat to its illusion of security. Sure, they'll name a wing of a new library after us when we're dead! But now... Now, when we're alive... Now, they wanna burn us at the stake!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: For example, I made love to your mother about half an hour ago and now I'm beginning to think that maybe it wasn't such a good idea.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I mean to say, I think Fay may be jealous.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't want to think about this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pointing at him) A poet has got to be able to think about anything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course you are! A great poet! But you need experience. You need to do something to be ashamed of every once in a while, for cryin' out loud.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on! Let's go out! There's a den of iniquity right across the street! You got any money?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . THE INFERNO -- NIGHT Later that night. Henry is dancing wildly on the bar with two sloppy-drunk topless dancers. The place is rocking and the crowd cheers them on. Simon sits perched on a stool, gripping the bar with white knuckles and clutching a beer, looking on in terror as... Henry starts stripping.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE GRIM HOUSE -- NIGHT Later that night. Simon stumbles in and heads upstairs. But he stops, seeing... Mary, sitting on the top step, smoking. She looks guilty and tense. So does Simon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She gets up and storms into her room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FAY'S ROOM -- NIGHT Moments later. Simon comes upstairs and stops outside his bedroom door when he sees... Fay, passed out drunk on her bed. Her clothes are half off and her lipstick smeared. She still grips a bottle of tequila in her hand. Simon hesitates, but then goes in and removes her shoes. He gets her out of her jacket and rolls her into the bed. Her bare limbs have their effect on Simon and he finds himself staring at her thigh. He reaches out and almost caresses her leg where her hiked- up skirt reveals the bottom of her behind. He catches himself, snaps his hand away and covers Fay with a blanket. He flees.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SIMON'S ROOM -- NIGHT Moments later. Simon is alone in the room with his bed. The pale sheets beckon. He is flushed. He blinks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE GRIM HOUSE KITCHEN -- NIGHT Moments later. He creeps down the stairs with an arm-load of books. Sitting at the table, he wrenches a nearby lamp into a more useful position and begins to read.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE GRIM HOUSE -- DAY The next morning. Henry stumbles up the stoop carrying a laptop computer, its various accessories and a couple of coffees. He lets himself in and dumps the computer on the kitchen counter. Simon is asleep on the couch, still in his clothes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry trudges back to the kitchen, where he whips out his red pen and immediately begins to correct Simon's poem. Simon rolls off the couch and makes his way to the table. Seeing the computer...

direction.raw_text: Simon looks over the computer and flips through the manual.

dialogue.raw_text: (shoving him) Simon. Hey, Simon. (Simon wakes) Come on. I got ya some coffee.

dialogue.raw_text: It's a computer. You write on it.

dialogue.raw_text: I stole it. Now listen. Remember how yesterday we discussed the relative desirability of cadence in relation to the readability of...

direction.raw_text: Simon does, but then...

Finally, in a pew off to one side in the shadows, they find... A young priest named Father Hawkes. He's a wreck. He looks up from his quiet sobbing and sees... Henry and Simon standing there looking on with embarrassed distaste. He lowers his head in shame. Henry moves closer and sits beside the distraught priest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The priest sighs hopelessly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry leans back with a sigh and reaches for his cigarettes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He offers a cigarette to the priest and he accepts.

dialogue.raw_text: Keep a look out. Tell me when he's gone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Henry, what's going on? Who is that guy? What's he want?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He wants to help me! He wants to be my friend.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So, you're an honest man. Why beat yourself up about it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know if there are grounds for faith. Is my vocation relevant? Does it make a difference?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The world. The way it is. Is this a way to help relieve suffering?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How can you be so sure?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Because vocation is the difference. Only someone who really cares doubts. Listen, father, as I was about to tell my friend Simon here, I am, without doubt, the biggest sinner within a hundred miles of this parish. But still, I've gotta stay up late at night to outdo the unending parade of mundane little atrocities I see committed every day right out in the open spaces of this loud and sunlit culture we call home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You seem to me to be a sensitive and generous man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I like to think so. But the fact is I appreciate depravity. Nevertheless, I insist your vocation makes a difference, because to hold out anything other than a spiritual yardstick to reality is to be jerking off grandly into the abyss. Listen, have you got any money? Let's go have a drink.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not supposed to talk about that stuff with people.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr Deng says you're some sort of a poet, or something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You tell Henry to call me -- Officer Bunuel -- pronto! Or they're gunna chuck his ass straight back into jail! Got it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't you even come near me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . THE GRIM HOUSE KITCHEN -- DAY Later.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon thinks of trying to explain, but then decides not to.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fay looks at the ceiling and sighs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They wait as the child goes outside. Mary listens, unseen, from her bedroom door. Fay comes over and frowns at her brother. She's about to lecture him, but he cuts her off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fay tries to control herself. She sighs tiredly and attempts to reason with him...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fay steps back, startled. Simon stands, but can't decide which way to go. He sits back down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary turns away from her door and sits on her bed. Fay leans over the stove, where a large pot of water is beginning to boil.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon is frustrated and lashes out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fay's mouth falls open and she staggers back, hurt. Simon regrets it already and stands to leave, scared. But Fay grabs the pot off the stove and hurls it at him, splashing boiling water all over his back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Outside, Pearl turns and looks back at the house. Simon lies gasping on the floor of the kitchen. Fay falls back against the stove, terrified and drops her head into her hands.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What do you mean, you quit?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There are things I want to do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: 'Opportunity will step out of the way to let a man... pass it by.'
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now you have to go out and get a job!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am not gettin' a job! (paces, then) Who's gunna look after Mom!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you treat Mom like a sick person, she's gunna stay like... you know, a sick person.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (banging the table) I am not retarded!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can see with my own eyes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mom can't be left alone with no one to keep an eye on her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, who's been keeping an eye on her while you've been out getting fucked by every OTB winner in town?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . THE GRIM HOUSE BATHROOM -- DAY Later. Fay is crouched on the floor, sobbing, while Simon lies in a tub of cold water. Mary comes in with a pathetic little freezer tray of ice cubes and dumps them into the tub. She steps back into the hall and throws the ice tray down the stairs. She glares back at Fay, who cries even louder as Simon stares up at the ceiling. Mary shakes her head and walks into her room, slamming the door behind her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon has no answers. But he reaches out and touches his sister's hand.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (sniffling) What happened to her, Simon? How did she get this way? Will it happen to me too? Huh? Why are we so fucked up?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . LIBRARY -- DAY Evening. Simon comes limping in, all stiff because of his scalded back. He's not familiar with the library, so he stands looking around, trying to figure it out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LIBRARY STACKS -- DAY Moments later. He wanders into an aisle, overwhelmed by all the books. Coming to the far end of the aisle, he looks off to his left and sees Henry sitting on a small stool, reading, with ten or twenty open volumes scattered around him on the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry sighs and sits back down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon blinks and looks down at his feet, unable to respond. Deeply hurt, he simply turns to walk away. But Henry reaches out and grabs his arm. Simon stops, pauses and looks back at his friend.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He lets go and turns away on his stool.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon comes back over to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry gives in slowly to the inevitable. He sighs deeply and stands, handing Simon a book...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon looks at the cover: Paradise Lost.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A young woman passes by, scanning the stacks. She and Henry have a split second of eye contact, then she turns and moves away. Henry straightens his tie and watches her go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry stops and turns. Simon pauses, then...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry watches him for a moment, then swaggers closer...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon waits for more but is disappointed. With one final cracked grin at his friend, Henry throws back his shoulders, slicks back his hair and strides off. Simon watches him go and frowns, not comforted. He flips through the pages of Paradise Lost.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (looking up and rising) Simon! What are you doing here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Henry... Your parole officer, Officer Bunuel, came by again today.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He told me to tell you that if you don't call him they're gunna put you back in jail.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He was talking to Mr Deng too, and, well, you know, I was thinking...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Simon, just shut the fuck up!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . Look, do me a favor. You got a library card?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Milton. Seventeenth century. English. You see, Simon, it's important my 'Confession' dig up the past, comb previous evidence and help chart the historic -- even the aesthetic -- inevitability of my ideas. And...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This place is crawling with chicks, Simon. Wander around. Leer a little. Cop a feel. Impose yourself on 'em. See what happens.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bullshit! You've got a rough hewn charm that sets 'em on edge. Now, listen, I gotta go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (voice over) 'Whereto with speedy words the arch- fiend replied Fallen Cherub, to be weak is miserable...'
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . LIBRARY READING ROOM -- DAY Moments later. He comes out from the stacks, working his way through the first page of Paradise Lost. He nearly bumps into a girl and they stop and look at one another. He tries to hold her gaze for a moment, challenging himself, but then turns away and stalks to a table. He sits and leans over the page. After a moment, though, he lifts his face and glances at... Another girl, sitting further down the table. She looks up from her reading and returns his gaze. He smiles at her. She gets up and leaves. Simon frowns, confounded and returns to his book. He takes out his notebook and pencil, meaning to take notes, but sees instead... A third girl sitting at another table, listening to her Walkman and typing her homework into a laptop computer. He finds himself staring at her and forces himself back to his book. But he can't help himself and glances back over at her. With a sigh, he begins to write in his notebook...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks back over at her. She happens to look up and their eyes meet. She smiles. Horrified, he looks down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He watches her again, thinks, then writes...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He writes a few moments more, scribbling across the page, then stops and looks back over at the girl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He tears out the page and folds it in half. Then he gets up and crosses the room to where the girl is busily engaged in her work. She looks up, sees him, and removes her headset with a pleasant smile. He places his note on the table before her, then turns and walks quickly away. The girl watches him go, confused, then lifts the note and reads...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: By now, Simon is gone from the library. The girl finishes reading the letter and looks around in astonishment.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (voice-over) Why is it this beautiful girl makes me sad? Does she know how beautiful she is? Do people tell her? Does she ever feel stupid?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why don't I smile when she looks at me? I look away. Ashamed of myself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Her figure makes me violent. I want to somehow break her. But tenderly. How is this possible? Ask Henry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (voice-over) Why do I do this to myself? And why do I reduce you to only one possibility? These are not even questions anymore. I know the answers myself. This isn't a page of notes. It's a letter. A letter to you. A desperate act. You are a miracle to me. I can't breathe.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . WORLD OF DONUTS -- DAY Evening. Henry enters and sits with Bunuel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry just glares at him and smokes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bunuel looks down, disappointed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry sits back, offended.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry leans back and sighs, furious and indignant.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: How 'bout those Alcoholics Anonymous meetings, did you go over and visit them yet?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What happened to this assistant librarian position you were supposed to set me up with?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I tried, Henry. I really did.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Henry, with your background... Well, I mean, with your record, they didn't think it'd be right to have you at the neighborhood library.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They thought you'd be a bad influence on the kids.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So my word is not enough. My promise worthless. The fact I've served my time nothing but the emblem of my continuing guilt.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . THE GRIM HOUSE -- NIGHT Simon comes in, excited and preoccupied, and finds Fay working at the computer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She shoves a sheath of papers up under his nose and he backs away in disgust.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon takes his notebooks from a cabinet above the fridge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He places the notebooks on the table and leaves the house. Fay clears the computer screen, pulls the notebooks closer and gets down to work.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm creating my resume. This computer's got a program especially for it. I bought some special stationery too. It's scented. Look.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can you type my poem into that thing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smokes, then) Simon, Mom's right about you. A poem's supposed to be a small, delicate kinda thing. Kinda feminine. Gentle. Look at this. You've made a fuckin' telephone book.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . HENRY'S APARTMENT -- NIGHT Moments later. Simon arrives with a six-pack and finds Henry sitting in front of the fire, staring into the flames, brooding darkly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He drinks, then looks at Simon and adds...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry stands and leans over the fire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He comes over and takes a beer. He strides around the room, thinking, reflecting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stops, drinks declares...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He approaches the notebooks lined up on the mantelpiece.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He glances over at Simon, who sits gripping his beer, watching, rapt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pauses and swills back some beer. He brightens up, gets excited...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Drinks sloppily, burps, wipes his mouth with his arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He smashes the bottle in the fireplace.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He grabs a new beer and twists off its cap.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He drinks, sighs and sits back down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon sits back in awe. He waits a moment and thinks. Finally he stands and approaches the 'Confession'. He reaches out and drags his hand across the notebooks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry sits staring into the flames again. He pauses, then...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I was caught. Yes, I was caught... once. I was caught in flagranti delicto screwing a thirteen-year-old girl named Susan. She was an ugly and mean-spirited kid, but she knew how to play upon my weaknesses which, I admit, are deep and many.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It was a pathetic little conspiracy. A transparently desperate attempt to discredit me and my ideas; to label me a mere pedophile. As if I'd be ashamed of such a thing. As if Socrates himself hadn't been taken out of circulation for corrupting the youth of Athens!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Seven years. Seven years for one afternoon of blissful transgression. But what of it? Who cares? Prison's not so bad; particularly if one's a sex offender, free from the popular and conventional horror of sodomy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I put them to good use. I began my major work. My opus.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Believe me, Simon, this incident with the girl, prison... It pales to insignificance in the wider context of my career.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing in comparison to the day my 'Confession' is unleashed. (beginning to pace) What an orgy we'll have then, huh? What shouts of outrage from the offended populace, from the sanctimonious purveyors of culture and quality, the righteous defenders of what ever inane and haphazard notion of progress then in vogue. They'll be beside themselves with fiercely reasoned critical analysis. Apoplectic with indignation!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, like a mirror which reflects only the inside of the person before it, my 'Confession' will lovingly render humanity's common monstrosity in all of its lurid wide screen glory.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why should I blush or feel shame before the common lot of humanity, anyway, for a few banal and, again I admit, inelegant transgressions?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: After all, really, I'm doing civilization a favor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CHURCH -- DAY Next day. Simon and Father Hawkes are deep in conversation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon listens and carefully considers all the priest says.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Father Hawkes pauses, then comes closer and sits.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We are told not to judge. But to forgive. Not to look into our neighbor's eye to find the bad, but to find the good. (pacing) Now this is difficult. I admit. (pause) But having a good friend is not always easy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, but... do you think Henry is... dangerous?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He needs help. Our help. Yours especially.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The best parts of himself come to the surface when he's helping someone learn. I've seen this. Let yourself be taught. Show your appreciation for his guidance. In this way, you know, perhaps. Well. There's hope for everyone. Even. Even Henry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . WORLD OF DONUTS -- DAY Fay comes walking up through the parking lot with Simon's notebooks and a pile of typed papers. She's a wreck; tear- stained face and a ball of tissues gripped in her hand like a weapon. She throws open the door to the World of Donuts and looks around. The place is crowded with teenagers hanging around like it was a cafe or student union. Fay sniffles tragically and falls on the counter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gnoc gets the Kleenex while Fay overhears two kids near Simon's poem...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fay pays for her tissues and makes her way to the back of the store where she finds Simon with Henry, who is holding forth to his friend and the small coterie of high school students surrounding them...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry takes the typed manuscript from her and continues...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fay blows her nose and Simon is concerned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She drops her head to the table and cries. Henry and Simon look on in silence. Then Henry continues...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Amy's girlfriend, Chris, leans forward studiously and asks...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon looks from her to Henry. Henry winks at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon signs the girl's book.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry seems a bit put upon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fay and Amy talk tech as...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry sips his beer and looks at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry reaches across the table and shakes Simon's hand.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Gnoc, gimme a value pack of Kleenex, will ya?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The violence of the imagery reminds me of early Clash, while the lyricism of the verse recalls, for me, Walt Whitman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I would have said Dickinson, maybe even Eliot, and so on. But I agree with the punk roots...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The greats all say the same thing: little. And what little there is to be said is immense. Or, in other words, follow your own genius to where it leads without regard for the apparent needs of the world at large, which, in fact, has no needs as such, but, rather, moments of exhaustion in which it is incapable of prejudice. (drinks) We can only hope to collide with these moments of unselfconsciousness. This divine fatigue... this...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: As I tried to make plain in Paris: 'Nous savons que nous avons chute parce que nous savons qui nous sommes.' 'We know we have fallen because we know who we are.'
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (interrupted) That's beside the point. But did they listen to me? Of course not!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (lighting a cigarette) No, I'm not alright! Your poem brought my period on a week and half early! So just shut up. Everybody just shut up!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: For is this not the best of all possible worlds? Are not the evils of this world necessary components of a cosmos that could not exist without them?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So, do you believe in God?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (lifting her head) Yeah, but when were you in Paris?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Simon, can I have your autograph?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go ahead. But never let yourself be flattered.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Henry) So what about this friend of yours, Hot Shot? The publisher.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. Angus James. How about sending this poem to him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Simon) When's it gunna be done, Simon?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, you oughta be home writing instead of hanging out over here with all your groupies.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Pardon me, swivel-hips. Is that your PowerBook?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (continues) The thing to do is to send parts of it to different magazines and literary journals first. That kinda thing. You know. Substantiate it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Filth, child. A preoccupation with excrement. Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's what the Board of Education called Simon's poem, yesterday; scatological.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . THE GRIM HOUSE KITCHEN -- DAY The next day. Fay is frying something on the stove, a cigarette hangs from her lip. A middle-aged woman with a press ID on her lapel appears at the kitchen door and taps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Intrigued, Fay steps over to the door with her spatula. She looks Edna over, studies her ID, then steps away and screams upstairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fay comes back over near the door, waving her spatula.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No response.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon finally shuffles into the kitchen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon says nothing. He just stares at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon just looks away, thinks, then wanders back upstairs. Mary passes him on his way out of the kitchen and comes up to Fay and Edna at the door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: My name is Edna Rodriguez and I write the human interest column for the Queens County Examiner and I was just wondering if I could have a word with Simon Grim?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can't talk to him for, you know, too long or anything, 'cause he's gotta, you know... he writes all day. That's all he does. Can you believe that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (calling again) Hey! Simon! Get down here!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Simon, this is Edna. She's from the newspaper.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (rapid fire) Simon, the Parents' Association at the local high school are calling your poem pornography. The teachers are defending the students' right to exercise their critical tastes and sensibilities. The county agrees with the Church and considers the poem emblematic of modern society's moral disintegration. How do you feel about these controversial reactions to your poem?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mom, this is Edna. Edna, Mom.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mrs Grim, what was Simon like as a child?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We all thought he was retarded.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And that's when all the trouble really started.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . HENRY'S APARTMENT -- DAY Henry is shaving. Simon sits in the kitchen, sorting through rejection letters...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon gives up and pushes the letters away, beaten.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry drops his razor and stomps out into the hall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon holds the stare, overwhelmed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon looks away, thinks a moment, then looks back at Henry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He goes back into the bathroom. Simon thinks a while, then...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No response.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Still no response. Simon gets up and stands in the bathroom doorway. Henry is shaving.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry puts down his razor and looks at Simon in the mirror.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He sees Simon looks worried.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He walks around the bathroom, gesticulating.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon patiently absorbs all this, then walks through the kitchen and looks across at the 'Confession' notebooks.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (reading) Dear Mr Grim, we here at the magazine consider ourselves and the publication open-minded and cutting edge and have consistently printed the work of the most brilliant and farseeing young talent of the day. Every week we are forced to return writing which we can not for one reason or another publish and include a brief but polite refusal. But this tract you've sent us demands a response as violent as the effect your words have had upon us. Drop dead. Keep your day job. Sincerely, The Editors.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: About taste. You can't argue about taste. God, Simon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The other twenty-five are almost as bad. I don't know why I bother.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you mean you don't know why you bother? You bother because you know the poem is excellent!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can you sit there, look me straight in the eye, and tell me you don't think this poem is great? That it is not at once a work of great lyrical beauty and ethical depth? That it is not a genuine, highly individual, and profound meditation on the miracle of existence?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So, you see, you have no choice!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (calling) Can you recommend it to your friend, the publisher?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Henry? Can you recommend the poem to him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I mean, I think it's finished and, for better or worse, it is book length.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That might not be as easy as it seems.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, it's been a long time. My name might not carry as much weight as it once did with Angus.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We were close at one time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You said he respected your opinion.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look, Simon, opinions come and go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: To be honest; my ideas, my writing, they haven't always been received well or even calmly. They're upsetting. I'm a controversial man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You see, what I'm doing is too radical. Too uncompromising. It'll take time for people to see its value. It's ahead of its time, perhaps, or maybe just... (stops) A recommendation from me might do you as much harm as it does good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Henry, why can't I read the 'Confession'?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Because certain work needs to be experienced all at once in order for one to appreciate the full force of its character.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . WORLD OF DONUTS -- DAY Simon talks with Fay as she eats her lunch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She gets up to go. She's wearing a smart outfit.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Simon, wake up! The guy's in a dream world!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's afraid that his reputation will prevent people from giving my work an honest chance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's kinda like in exile. Marginalized on account of his ideas.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If he's such a great big fat genius, why doesn't he write books? Like you do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He has. He's written a book. It's almost completed. He's been working on it for years. It's just not published.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, I bet. It's probably disgusting.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (defensively) It's a quite serious and difficult piece of work, apparently.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. Not yet. Soon. Certain work needs to be experienced all at once in order for one to appreciate the full force of its character.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, well, what ever. Listen, Simon, forget Henry. Go straight up to this Angus James character yourself and make him read your poem.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm gunna apply for a job at the one- hour photo joint and then go over to the Mall to see about that job in the bank. Make sure Mom takes her pills. See ya.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . THE GRIM HOUSE -- DAY Mary is sitting, brooding in front of the TV, which displays only static white noise. She turns it off with the remote and sits in silence for a moment. She gets off the couch and moves to the kitchen table, where Fay's computer sits. She goes over and reaches up above the fridge, opening the cabinet containing Simon's notebooks. She hesitates, then takes them down and holds them in her hands, as if to begin reading. But then she puts them back.
