She walks over to the piano and stands there, hesitating, before slowly sitting down and opening it. She lifts her hands to play, then pauses and looks around behind her, making sure no one is there. But, finally, she turns back and begins playing. She plays a sad-sounding modern classical piece with rusty accomplishment. At one time she was probably quite good. She plays for a while, gradually letting herself become moved by the music. But then she stops, pauses, and looks behind her. Simon is standing in the kitchen. He has been deeply affected by her playing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She stares him down a moment longer, then looks away and closes the piano. She returns to the couch and switches on the TV. Simon comes closer. He sits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon waits. Eventually...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She gets up off the couch and goes upstairs. She slams her bedroom door and leaves Simon alone on the couch. He thinks. Then, he gets up and goes into the kitchen. He takes the typed manuscript of his poem from the cabinet above the refrigerator and goes to the door. He pauses, clutches the poem and goes out.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: That was nice what you were playing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, it was nice. But it was unremarkable.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looking right at him) Yes. It does.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . SUBWAY STATION -- DAY Simon waits, clutching his poem to his side, as a train pulls into the station. Excited and determined, he gets on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . TRAIN -- DAY Simon travels to New York City. He finds an envelope on the floor to put the poem in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MARY'S ROOM -- DAY Mary wakes up and sits on the edge of the bed, feeling regretful about her tone of voice with Simon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE GRIM HOUSE KITCHEN -- DAY Moments later. Mary comes down into the kitchen and listens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No answer. She steps over to the cabinet and almost takes down Simon's notebook. But doesn't. She grabs her pills and is about to take them. But then she stops. She puts them down and goes to the cabinet. She takes down Simon's notebooks and sits at the table, pauses, then pulls them closer and begins to read.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PUBLISHING HOUSE LOBBY -- DAY Simon enters a big, posh lobby and checks the registry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PUBLISHING HOUSE RECEPTION -- DAY Moments later. Simon comes out of the elevator and enters the reception area of James Midriff and Sutton Publishing. He walks hesitantly up to the receptionist, a bright and spirited young woman named Laura.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon steps back defensively.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Laura steps back, cocks her head and removes her designer eye-wear.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Are you here to fix the plumbing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm here to see Mr. Angus James.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not a plumber. Or a messenger. I was once a garbage man. But now I'm a poet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CONFERENCE ROOM -- DAY Same time. Angus is at a big table with two other men, Steve and Barry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Laura knocks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve and Barry nod.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And she's gone.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The book, as we know it, Angus, will be a thing of the past within the next few years. Novels, articles, newspapers will all be downloaded on to our personal computers anyway.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So you're telling me to get out of the publishing business?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. But we've got to re-invent the publishing business for the electronic age.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry to disturb you, gentlemen, but... Angus, there's a particularly wound-up young garbage man out here who seems to have written a poem. A long poem. And I recall how, at last month's meeting, you stressed the need for us to be on the look-out for more marginalized verse from unestablished quarters of the American scene.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, OK. Make an appointment, Laura. Sometime next month.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (returning) So, anyway, how is the digital revolution going to help me sell books?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . PUBLISHING HOUSE RECEPTION -- DAY Simon looks disappointed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon just looks down at his shoes. Laura touches his arm and reassures him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks up, pauses, then...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Why can't I see him now?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sincerely) Because he's a very important man and, well, you're not.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CONFERENCE ROOM -- DAY Same time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Laura re-enters...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I don't think people are going to prefer reading books on television, Steve.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Angus, look, we have a number of charts here...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In every home in America the PC will be where the TV used to be.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And it'll be a direct connection to all forms of media.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: An unprecedented transformation of American social life...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We'll all become better informed, more literate, increasingly productive, and... Well, and, like I said, we have a number of charts...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sorry to disturb you again, gentlemen, but... Angus, I'd like to call security for this one. Though, before I do, I just wanted to ask just how marginal the as yet undiscovered voice of American poetry should be?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's been denounced by his local Board of Education.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, I read about him in the paper. Hangs out in a delicatessen somewhere and writes pornography.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . PUBLISHING HOUSE RECEPTION -- DAY Moments later. Angus comes out to the water cooler and glares at Simon as he gets a drink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He grabs the envelope and sees no title.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon is stumped. He looks over at Laura, who purses her lips and tilts her head. He twists a button on his shirt, thinking, then returns to Angus.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon looks over at Laura.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hello, and why do you think I should take valuable time out of my busy schedule to read...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wouldn't want to waste your time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sure you wouldn't and I appreciate you being so straightforward.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I assume you can take straightforward criticism?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hold my calls for the next half hour.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He doesn't drink coffee. Steve, do you drink coffee?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . WORLD OF DONUTS -- DAY Henry paces back and forth. With the fingers of one hand pressed against his forehead and his eyes closed tight in concentration, he dictates to Amy, who is sitting at a table with her laptop computer, typing his every word.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Amy types away, fascinated by Henry's intelligence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stops, zeroing in on his point.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He smokes, drinks, paces some more. Amy waits with bated breath, devastated by his obscure profundity. He comes back and sits beside her, reaching his conclusion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She gazes at his profile, in love. Henry sits thinking and Amy watches him reverently. She leans over close and whispers in his ear. He turns and looks at her, alarmed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry jumps up and looks around, paranoid. He keeps his voice down and points at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Disappointed, Amy turns away and sulks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry sees she's genuinely upset and feels bad. He sits back down and lays his hand on hers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now Henry tries to scare her away. He leers at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She just stares at him, blinks, then looks away and tries to imagine this. She takes her laptop and leaves, confused and blushing. Henry watches her go and grins, satisfied with himself.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: In the infinite amplitude of his love, God wants to create the largest number of best elements that can exist together in one cosmos... OK.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In an instantaneous calculation made in eternity, God computes the best possible world and creates it. Fine. This 'decision' by God is uncontingent and eternal rather than temporally or ontologically sequential.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ... Don't you have some kinda spell-check on that thing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It is impossible for every perfect good to be compatible with every other perfect good. The intense beauty of the mountain must be set off by the fertility of the plain, so to speak.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The good of freewill must entail real choices for sin.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Listen, Amy, back off. I'm on parole.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You feel the same way. I can tell. I can see it when you look at me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey! I don't look at you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes you do. In the street. In the parking lot yesterday. That night on the highway.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I look at a lot of people that way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, as a matter of fact, I think you're a real bright kid and I like that about you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I like it so much I've got half a mind to do perverse things to you. Right here. Right now. Things you might just learn to like.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . PUBLISHING HOUSE RECEPTION -- DAY Angus throws on his coat and thrusts the poem at Simon as they walk down the hall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon looks pale as Angus strides towards the elevator.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They reach the elevator and stop. Simon tries to catch his breath.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon hesitates, almost decides against it, but then...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Angus looks back at him. Simon waits. Angus looks aside, thinks, then shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon just looks at him blankly, confused. The doors slide open and Angus gets in the elevator. He's gone. Simon sinks into a chair and stares at the carpet. He is so surprised and hurt he gasps for breath. His poem slips from his hand and falls to the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon doesn't register this right away. But then he looks up and over at the receptionist. Laura stands and comes around her desk. She pauses, seeing his disappointment, then comes closer and picks up his poem. Handing it to him, she explains...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He just stares at her, demolished.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: This is really quite unbelievably bad, my friend. I mean, I'm all for experimentation and I've made a career out of a healthy disregard for convention, but... Look, this is profoundly irrelevant material. This is only my opinion. But it's an opinion I value highly. Goodnight, Laura. Call Norton Press. We're still on for tomorrow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've been wrong before as a publisher. But I refuse to admit I've ever been wrong as a reader. You have talent, I admit. You have an innate sense of the musicality of language. A good ear, maybe. But you do nothing significant with it. And this twisted reasoning that poses as... conviction or insight, it's... well, it's embarrassing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why did you bring this thing to me, anyway?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (weakly) A friend of mine spoke of you. He said you had a lot of integrity.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, well, of course, I do. But I'm not crazy, am I? Who is this person? Do I know him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He used to be the janitor here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . SIDEWALK/SUBWAY ENTRANCE -- DAY Later. Simon dumps his poem in a trash can, pauses, then enters the subway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . WORLD OF DONUTS -- DAY Henry is leaning on the counter, flipping through pornographic magazines and smoking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry flips through pages and nods, impressed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry looks up, outraged.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry throws his cigarette to the floor, steps on it and returns to his magazine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry shakes his head in dismay and studies a centerfold.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm just looking at the pictures.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I learn so much from these magazines, Mr Deng. I refuse to discriminate between modes of knowing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And you can't smoke in here anymore.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This place is losing all its charm, Mr Deng.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Business is good. The kids, they hang out all day and drink coffee, talk about art and read poetry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's just a fad, Mr Deng. These kids today, they're just slaves to fashion.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . THE GRIM HOUSE KITCHEN -- DAY Same time. Fay comes in, hot and tired from walking around in high heels.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She stands on the stairs and hears the water running in the bathroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No answer. She discovers she's out of cigarettes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . WORLD OF DONUTS -- DAY Henry is leaning on the counter with a six-pack of beer, pleading with Mr Deng.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Warren comes in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Warren reaches for his wallet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry pays Mr Deng for his beer.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Come on, Mr Deng! How much do I owe you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That can't be right! And so what? My credit's good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Warren, you gotta couple of bucks I can borrow?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Listen, Henry, I wanna remind you to vote this Thursday.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah, yes, of course. When noble minds shrink from the task of leadership scoundrels will rush in to fill the void. (takes cash) Thanks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's every American's right. A blessing. Yet another opportunity to save America from itself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . HENRY'S APARTMENT -- DAY Moments later. Fay bangs on the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No answer. She tries the door. It's open. She hesitates.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She goes quietly in.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Henry, you in there? Gimme a cigarette.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . WORLD OF DONUTS -- DAY Moments later. Henry steps out of the store and stops when he sees Amy standing there, pouting. He looks away and sighs. Amy picks at the fabric of her stockings and bites her lip.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry smokes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's more than he can stand. He holds his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Crushed, she breaks out in tears and flees.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What kind of... Well, I mean... What kind of... perverse things would you do to me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . THE GRIM HOUSE -- DAY Same time. Simon comes in, furious and throws open the fridge. He finds nothing to eat or drink. He slams the door, then hears the water running in the bathroom upstairs. He stops and listens. The bathroom door; the water heard running steadily. Simon turns away then sees... The poem notebooks face down on the table. He thinks. The bathroom door; the water heard running...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HENRY'S APARTMENT -- DAY Moments later. Henry comes into his house, hot and bothered, cradling his six-pack. But he stops, listens, then steps through the kitchen towards the living-room. He stops in the entrance and sees... Fay on the floor of the living-room, reading his 'Confession', her mouth hung open in an astonished 'O'. He drops his six-pack and... She spins around, caught in the act. Henry stands in the doorway, pent up, sweating and with perverse things on his mind. Fay, her hands palm down on the floor behind her, bites her lip, coquettishly. Henry looks her over like she was something good to eat. She feels his gaze all over her and twists to one side with a breathless little shudder. He steps nearer, stands over her and she looks up at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE GRIM HOUSE -- DAY Same time. Simon climbs the stairs to the bathroom...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HENRY'S APARTMENT -- DAY Same time. Henry and Fay kissing passionately...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE GRIM HOUSE -- DAY Same time. Simon knocks on the bathroom door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HENRY'S APARTMENT -- DAY Same time. Henry and Fay groping and shoving one another as they stagger from room to room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE GRIM HOUSE -- DAY Same time. Simon bangs on the bathroom door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HENRY'S APARTMENT -- DAY Same time. Fay falls to the couch...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE GRIM HOUSE -- DAY Same time. Simon crashes through the door and finds... Mary, kneeling over the edge of the tub, her wrists slit and the blood running down the drain, the shower raining down over her back. Simon looks on in horror.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HENRY'S APARTMENT -- DAY Same time. Henry tears open his trousers...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE GRIM HOUSE -- DAY Same time. Simon lifts Mary from the bathtub.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HENRY'S APARTMENT -- DAY Same time. Henry and Fay clutch and grind and heave...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE GRIM HOUSE -- DAY Same time. Simon drags his mother from the bathroom and down the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HENRY'S APARTMENT -- DAY Same time. Henry and Fay are making mad, passionate love, oblivious to the world around them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . GRIM HOUSE DAY -- DAY Same time. Simon drags Mary through the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HENRY'S APARTMENT -- DAY Same time. Henry and Fay fuck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE GRIM HOUSE -- DAY Same time. Simon drags Mary out the kitchen door and into the yard, looking desperately for help. He reaches the street, her limp body hanging grotesquely before him, and looks helplessly up and down the block.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CEMETERY -- DAY Simon, Henry, Mr Deng, Fay, Gnoc and Bunuel stand with Father Hawkes at the grave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He sprinkles holy water on the coffin and they all drop carnations at the grave. Simon and Fay remain there looking down at the coffin. Henry waits for them a few yards away, wishing he could help, but feeling out of place.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Let us pray. Lord, grant that peace be within reach for our friend, Mary. May the pain and confusion she endured on earth be fought through in the after life, so that she may enter the Kingdom of Heaven and live in the light of God. Amen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . JUNKYARD -- DAY Simon is back working on the garbage truck. He collects garbage and throws it in the truck as Henry, who is just along for the ride, hangs from the side of the truck and pulls the lever whenever Simon tells him to.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry shrugs and qualifies...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry pulls the lever and the garbage gets crushed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry is about to pull the lever again, but sees something in amongst the garbage...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry steps down and leans over into the garbage. Simon joins him as he lifts something that is either a ring or a stray piece of machinery.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry puts it in his pocket, satisfied and Simon jumps on the back of the truck as it turns the corner and rolls away. Henry starts to walk off in the opposite direction, but stops when he sees Pearl age seven.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: So I was a janitor! So what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But Angus James said he didn't even know you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I mean, we weren't like bosom buddies or anything. But we used to talk sometimes. In the elevator. In the morning. He said he liked my ideas. Being a janitor's a good job if you're a writer. Especially the night shift; all that time to think and develop my ideas.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, what the hell does he know? He wouldn't know a vital piece of literary art if it came up and bit him in the leg. To hell with him! He's not the only publisher in the world!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smokes) It's true. A prophet is seldom heeded in his own land. Remember that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think it's a gasket. A fitting from off of that old refrigerator over there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . VICKY'S HOUSE -- DAY Henry comes up the street with Pearl age seven on his back. He walks into Vicky's yard and finds Warren lifting weights in the garage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Warren rests. He sits up on the bench and takes a toke off the joint he has waiting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry pauses, then leads Pearl age seven towards the house. Warren lies back down and continues his lifting.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Warren, I found Pearl wandering around by the garbage dump.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (realizing) Oh. Well, you know. Somebody's gotta lose.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's the fucking use. You make sacrifices. You try to be a decent human being. Try to contribute something meaningful to society. And what happens? They lose to a bunch of cultural elite liberal fuck-ups. I don't give a shit anymore. People deserve what they get.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . VICKY'S HOUSE -- DAY Moments later. Henry knocks on the door as he enters...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No answer. He comes in and finds her sitting on the couch with a drink. She's got a black eye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pearl comes over and stands beside her mother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vicky caresses Pearl's hair, then drinks and looks over at Henry.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: He's a good man, Henry. Nobody's perfect.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I found Pearl wandering around with no shoes on her feet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . WORLD OF DONUTS -- DAY Moments later. Bunuel is waiting when Henry walks in and steps up to the beer cooler.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry looks at the man, disgusted, then falls in to a seat and motions to Gnoc, who is now the waitress.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He unfolds a print-out of the letter. Henry reads and Bunuel leans over, pointing out...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry thinks this over, gulps back some espresso and nods his approval. Then...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry is impressed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bunuel gets up to go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is having ideas.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: No more beer. Coffee. Espresso! Cappuccino! Cafe au lait. Carrot juice. Herbal tea.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A double espresso and a jelly donut, Gnoc. (to Bunuel) You mind paying? My credit's no good here anymore, apparently.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nods amiably) Did you go to the employment agency today, Henry?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, but it's OK. Simon's gunna try to get me a job on the garbage truck.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Listen, I'm a little concerned about your friend.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Seems he gave an obscene note to a girl in the library.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It almost certainly is. He mentions you. Look...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: 'Her figure makes me violent. I want to somehow break her. But tenderly. How is this possible? Ask Henry.'
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bunuel, this is obviously a love letter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She posted it on the Internet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She was trying to warn other girls about a potential rapist.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smokes) Is all this true about the Internet? About how you can get pornography on it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, yeah, sure. It's a big problem. You can send dirty pictures and everything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (thinking) Sure. See you. (calls the waitress) Gnoc, gimme one of these double espressos to go, will ya?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . THE GRIM HOUSE KITCHEN -- DAY Moments later. Fay, still dressed in black, is tapping away on the keys to the computer, surfing the Internet, as Henry appears at the kitchen door, gripping his tall double espresso.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She turns and glares at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry stops, pauses, looks away. Then...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He changes the subject again, preoccupied and continues tenderly...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He sighs and drinks his coffee, then looks back at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fay is tempted.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frowning, she reconsiders. She gets up and takes the notebooks from the cabinet above the fridge. She flips through the pages but suddenly stops and turns to the door with a nicer attitude.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But he's gone. It's as if he has vanished into thin air. She sighs, sits back down, and begins typing the poem onto the Internet.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You gotta get outta the house, Fay. You can't blame yourself for not being here. You did all you could for her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You got the Internet on that contraption?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look Fay, about, you know, between us -- what happened...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't wanna talk about it, Henry!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Type a part of Simon's poem onto the Internet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on, Fay. It's a great idea.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know if he would want us to do that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure he would. Just the first ten verses.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He'll thank you for it later.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . WORLD OF DONUTS -- DAY Moments later. Henry comes back into the store, satisfied with himself. He finishes off his coffee, tosses away the cup and takes a pornographic magazine from the rack. He leans on the counter where Mr Deng is busy working and flips through the pages.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Deng starts to make him one and sees him with the magazine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Deng shakes his head and frowns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Deng brings over the coffee. Henry is surprised to notice he is not riveted.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry closes the magazine and puts it back. Leaning on the counter, he sips his coffee and ponders.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Deng just goes back to work, leaving Henry there at the counter thinking big thoughts.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Gimme another one of those tall double espressos, Mr Deng.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's this fascinating story about a famous rock band and how they tied a friend of theirs to a bed in their hotel room and inserted a live fish into her vagina.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (explains) They say she had numerous orgasms.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Henry, you need to do something with your life. Get a job, or something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I mean, it wasn't the entire fish, it was just, you know, the nose. The nose of the fish.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You ever wonder what it would be like to have sex with an animal, Mr Deng?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That coffee is free. Just take it and get out of here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I mean, some dogs are almost as big as people and often more attractive.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . THE GRIM HOUSE -- EVENING Simon hangs from the garbage truck as it comes up the street and pauses in front of his house. He jumps down and the truck barrels away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FAY'S ROOM -- EVENING Simon taps at the door. She looks over at him and he sees she's been crying. He comes into the room and she sits up on the edge of the bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He comes over and sits beside her. He thinks a moment, then...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And she starts crying again. Simon awkwardly touches her shoulder, then moves his hand away. Fay pulls herself together, sniffles and goes into the bathroom.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You've got to tell him, Fay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Moments later. Simon comes downstairs and finds Henry at the piano. He looks ill and is clutching a nearly empty container of espresso. He is staring sickly at 'the ring'.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon lifts the coffee container and smells it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry tries to remember. He squints.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon puts the container down and sits at the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry grabs his stomach. He presses his hand against his chest, holds his head, then stares at the ring.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks at Simon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry looks at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry lets this sink in. He stands and the room tilts. White with fear, he clutches at his rumbling gut.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: INT.
location: THE GRIM HOUSE, AT THE PIANO

dialogue.raw_text: Simon, I don't feel so good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I feel all kinda clammy. And damp.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How many of these did you have?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How much you think I can get for this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Moments later. Fay is in the shower as... Henry bursts into the bathroom, tearing at his belt and trousers. She starts screaming and wraps herself in the shower curtain. He drops his pants and throws himself on the toilet just in time to begin shitting his brains out. Fay crouches, terrified and disgusted, in the shower.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry sweats and moans as he empties his bowels in a violent and messy blast of noise and foul air. Fay covers her face and whimpers sickly. Finally, he's done. He hangs with his face out over his knees, sick, exhausted and in shock. Fay wraps herself in a towel and steps out of the shower. She creeps carefully around him and flushes the toilet, growing increasingly concerned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is destroyed, staring down at... The 'ring' he still holds in his hand. Fay sees this, looks at Henry, then kneels and takes it from him. He doesn't resist. She lifts it up and breathlessly admires it. Totally misunderstanding, moved beyond words...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And she throws her arms around him as he sits there, sweating and spent, on the toilet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CHURCH -- DAY A month later. Mr Deng and Bunuel drag Henry, kicking and screaming, into the church foyer. Once inside, he shakes them off and they stand back. He huffs and puffs and tosses the hair back out of his eyes. He paces back and forth like a caged animal, then stops, sees... Fay, at the altar, waiting with Simon. She is beautiful. Henry calms down, deeply affected. Fay smiles down the aisle at him. Henry throws back his shoulders, straightens his tie and strides up the aisle. Also present at the ceremony are Vicky and Warren. Gnoc is maid of honor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CHURCH -- DAY Later. Henry holds Fay's hand and repeats after Father Hawkes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The gasket everyone is now mistaking for a ring is lifted high before the altar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The gasket is placed on Fay's finger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The doors of the church swing open with a tremendous creak and everyone turns from the altar to see... Amy enter. She steps in and stands there, alarmed, clutching a long scroll of fax paper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon walks down the aisle to see to Amy. The guests watch and wait. As Simon reaches her, Amy looks away from the altar and shows him the fax scroll.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He studies the fax and recognizes his poem. He grows concerned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon looks up the aisle at... Fay and Henry. They look away, caught.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Confused, Simon starts for the door, shoving the fax in his pocket. Fay steps down from the altar...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Amy hurries along beside him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Henry, take you, Fay to be my wife.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Henry, take you, Fay to be my wife.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And do promise before God and these witnesses...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And do promise before God and these witnesses...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: To be your loving and faithful husband.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: To be your loving and faithful husband.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: For as long as we both shall live.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: For as long as we both shall live.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bless, O Lord, this ring, that he who gives it and she who wears it may abide in your peace and continue in your favor until their life's end.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Whom God has joined, let no man separate.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're even talking about it on the TV news.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's a guy from the radio station over at World of Donuts and a story in the newspaper about some kids burning down a school near Boston!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . THE GRIM HOUSE -- NIGHT Later that evening. The whole neighborhood is celebrating Fay's wedding. The music is loud. The people are drunk. The place is a shambles. A big dance number is playing. Amidst all the festivities, though, Simon and Bunuel have the small TV propped up on top of the fridge, following the evening news...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fay leads the neighbors in the dance...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry and Fay dance, surrounded by the dancing neighbors...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry throws an arm around Warren, who stands looking dejected in the doorway, and raises his glass to the happiness in the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The TV is switched off. It's later now. People are passed out on the kitchen floor and various neighbors are sitting around the table. Fay steps back from the TV, drains a glass of beer and wipes her mouth on the sleeve of her wedding gown. She hugs Simon, who is deeply unsettled by the news of his growing infamy.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (on TV) It all started right here in Queens, Jim, at World of Donuts about one year ago today, when local garbage man, Simon Grim, put pencil to paper and began to compose what many have come to regard as vicious, antisocial and pornographic poetry -- 112 lines of unrhymed free meter verse which would one day serve to spark the flames of controversy across the nation and -- indeed -- the world.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (on TV) This is outrageous! Measures must be taken. Have we debased our culture to such an extent that a garbage man with a head full of sick ideas is legitimately referred to as a poet, and where the filth he spews can be accessed by any child old enough to turn on a computer? Is this what we have come to? Not the transmission of our highest ideals, but a cynical, atheistic delirium!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (on TV) Poetry of this kind, and this poem in particular, is, I think, a worthy form of desperation; a digression on the extremes of human experience; of solitude, of community. It is perhaps alarming, even upsetting to some -- myself included -- but it must be allowed to exist.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (on TV) Meanwhile, in Rome today, the Pope issued a message of hope for believers in their fight against what he termed the godless and lost. He did not mention Simon Grim by name, but offered a prayer for the young whom he described as sadly in need of faith and not the illusion of conviction offered by rock music, drugs and contemporary poetry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: God, Simon, I mean, like, you're a total fucking rock star.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . WORLD OF DONUTS -- DAY A huge crowd of kids are pressed up against the doors, trying to get a peek at their hero, Simon Grim. Angus comes away from the window. He stands and regards Simon, who is sitting at a table tearing a napkin to shreds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He points to the fans outside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon thinks this over, but says nothing. Angus comes over and lays his hand on his shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon nods.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Because I think your writing will be tremendously successful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What made you change your mind?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Other people's responses. I don't live in a vacuum, you know. Two months ago I didn't have the proof of your poem's appeal. Now I do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Consider my offer carefully. Get some professional advice. I'll call you tomorrow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . WORLD OF DONUTS -- DAY Moments later. Angus emerges and has to fight his way through the throng of excited adolescents. He reaches his limo and gets in. But he pauses before closing the door and considers the crowd. Simon emerges from the store and kids begin screaming and shouting for autographs. Angus shakes his head, impressed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CHURCH -- DAY Simon consults Father Hawkes.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: A hundred thousand in cash up front.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, that could be better. But it is a hundred thousand dollars up front. Guaranteed money. You could use that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. Try to get him up to a hundred and fifty thousand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . JUNKYARD -- DAY Evening. Henry stalks along, all fired up. Simon tries his best to keep up with him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He collapses extravagantly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry glances back at his friend, digesting this. He thinks it over, then...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Having finally got through to him, Simon comes forward, anxious to help Henry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He paces back and forth, thrusting out his chest, for the first time in his life displaying something like pride or arrogance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry sits there watching Simon, impressed with this evidence of increased self-esteem. He realizes the profundity of the gesture.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon stares off into the distance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry is moved. He stands and comes forward. He grabs his friend by the shoulders and turns him around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry steps away, considering, then looks back at Simon and extends his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon smiles. Henry smiles. They shake hands.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I've let myself down, Simon! I've let myself be caught in the bloody maw of banal necessity! How did I get here? How did this happen to me? I'm going to be somebody's father! I need time to think. To write. Time to finish my 'Confession'! I can't work for a living! It's impossible! I tried once. My genius will be wasted trying to make ends meet!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is how great men topple, Simon. Their hearts are in the right place too much of the time! They get sidetracked! Distracted. Oh! How could I have been so careless!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Henry, please, let me read the 'Confession'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. Not now. It's not done. I'm all washed up. I'm finished!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Angus James is convinced my poem is going to make him incredibly wealthy. He'll read your book and seriously consider publishing it. If I ask him to. I'm certain.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (adds) Or I won't let him publish my poem.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'd do that? You'd do that for me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you realize what you're saying?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . HENRY'S APARTMENT -- DAY Simon enters, comes forward into the room and pauses, looking off at... The stack of twelve books that comprise the 'Confession'.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HOUSE/BACKYARD -- DAY Henry stands outside, watching his door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HENRY'S APARTMENT -- DAY Simon lifts the first volume, opens it and begins reading. He sits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BACKYARD -- DAY Henry paces, drinking and smoking nervously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HENRY'S APARTMENT -- NIGHT Simon strides the length of the living room, reading. He stops, frowns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HENRY'S APARTMENT -- NIGHT Simon reads in front of the fire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BACKYARD/GARAGE -- NIGHT Bunuel, Hawkes and Mr Deng sleep sitting up as Henry talks to himself. Fay leans out the back door and interrupts him. He looks at her, but says nothing. She sighs and goes back inside: turning off the lights.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HENRY'S APARTMENT -- DAY The next morning. Simon sits wearily reading the final page of volume twelve as the morning sun streaks into the room. Finally, he finishes and slowly closes the book. He stands and crosses the room. Leaning against the wall, he removes his glasses and rubs his aching eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BACKYARD -- DAY Simon steps out of Henry's apartment and sees Henry asleep on the back stoop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . WORLD OF DONUTS -- DAY Simon stares into a glass of water. Fay sits ten feet away, waiting. Finally...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . ANGUS JAMES' OFFICE -- DAY The 'Confession' lies on the big desk. Angus' hand comes down upon it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Angus pauses and figures. He changes the subject.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is at a loss for words.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon waits a while, staring at his shoes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon sits and lets this sink in. Angus waits, then...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon continues looking out at the city. Angus waits, but there is no response. Finally, Simon turns, pauses and slowly crosses the room. He sits at the table and looks down at the contract. He signs.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: And you want me to consider publishing it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Simon, this book, it's... It's really quite bad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's what you said about my poem.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm offering you a very real expression of my faith in your writing. Two hundred thousand dollars and a sixty/forty split.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But just exactly what is the nature of your faith in my writing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look, Simon, you don't require my admiration. You require my experience as a publisher. And that experience leads me to believe your poem will make more money than any book of poetry ever published. In history. Virtually make you a household name within two years. You'll never have to work on a garbage truck again, I assure you. Or do anything else for that matter. Whereas this 'Confession' by Henry Fool...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The most I can say for this is... The man is a scoundrel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He taught me everything I know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No! He encouraged all that was expressive in you to become manifest. He inspired you to act. He influenced your perception.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How about if my advance is only a hundred thousand?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We could split the royalties seventy/thirty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I will not publish Henry Fool's 'Confession'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . THE GRIM HOUSE KITCHEN -- DAY Fay is in labor. Henry helps her into her coat as they rush for the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . WORLD OF DONUTS -- DAY Moments later. Henry runs into the store and stands there, panicked, looking at Hawkes, Bunuel and Mr Deng. Gnoc runs out to get Fay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . WORLD OF DONUTS -- DAY Henry and Gnoc load Fay into the van. The van pulls out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . VAN -- DAY Henry drives recklessly. Fay rolls around in the back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HOSPITAL CORRIDOR -- DAY Fay is in a wheelchair being rushed down the hall. She is gripping Henry's hand as he runs along beside her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HOSPITAL DELIVERY ROOM -- DAY Fay gasps and sweats as the Doctor and Nurse prepare her. She is scared. She looks over at... Henry, looking in through the window. He looks scared too. Fay is sedated by gas. Henry is taken away by the Nurse. Fay stares up at the ceiling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HOSPITAL WAITING ROOM -- NIGHT Henry is asleep on a row of waiting-room chairs, exhausted. Simon comes running up the hall and finds him. It's late and no one is around. He sits down beside Henry and shakes him. Henry wakes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He sits up and Simon sits beside him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon sits back, relieved. Then he remembers the rain-soaked shopping bag he has with him. He pulls out a couple of cans of beer and hands one to Henry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They look around, seasoned conspirators and make sure the coast is clear. Then they pop open the beers and toast. They drink. Then...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon pauses, scared, then gets up and crosses the room. He looks out of the window and gathers his strength.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry looks at Simon blankly, then blinks and looks away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Silence. Simon comes back and sits again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon just stares at him blankly, then sighs and shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon comes over and lays his hand on Henry's shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He steps away and sits. Henry pauses, then approaches and leans down over him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry stands there a moment longer, then lowers himself into the nearest seat, weakened.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon's words catch in his throat. He turns away, frustrated.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry just stares at him, stands, then turns on his heel and waves him off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon hangs his head, destroyed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry is scared all of a sudden. But he puts on a defiant exterior.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He stands, drinks and walks over to the window...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry take advantage of Simon's disillusionment and puts on a big show of secure wisdom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon sits there a moment, numb with grief. Henry, red in the face, stares at the floor. Suddenly, Simon stands and walks out. Henry looks up and watches him go. He can hardly believe it. He almost raises his voice and apologizes, but can't. He lowers his head again and covers his face with his hands, listening to Simon's footsteps receding through the halls. Simon walks on, away from us, down the hospital corridor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . STREET -- DAY Seven years later. Fay bangs out of the kitchen door with her seven-year-old son Ned. Frazzled and overworked, she grips a loaded laundry basket to her side as she sits Ned down on the curb and points at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The kid sits still, obviously guilty of some unspeakable mischief, as Fay storms back into the house. He looks around, bored, then brightens up when he sees... Henry, coming up the street, hanging from the back of a garbage truck.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Listen, Henry, Angus James didn't like your 'Confession'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah. I see. Well, what now?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I mean, after all, there are things I can do to make it more accessible.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can soften up some of the language and make it read easier. Take out some of the more intratextual references and popularize the underlying Sturm und Drang, so to speak. I can change its mode. Make it more of a conventional novel instead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (laughing) Oh, Simon, don't be such a purist! I appreciate your protectiveness, but the integrity of the work gives it a durability that can sustain such things.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you saying; that it doesn't merit revision?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm saying... Angus James didn't like it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, did you tell him what you think?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, it does. You've got to use your influence with him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I gave it to him to read and he hated it. What more can I do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can refuse to let him publish your poem.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That was before I read your book.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looking up at him) I signed the contract, Henry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look, Henry, what did you expect?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (indignantly) Look, if I had told you, when at first I read it, that I thought it was no good, what would you have done?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I would have respected your opinion.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And insisted that there's no accounting for taste.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know. I didn't bring it to Angus because I thought it was good. I brought it to Angus because you're my friend.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (staggered) Oh how perfectly enormous of you, Simon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (explodes) Look, Henry, I did it! I wrote. I wrote poetry because you told me to! I worked! I worked while you sat back and comfortably dismissed the outside world as too shallow, stupid and mean to appreciate your ideas.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is that such a priority? Is that some sort of measure of a man's worth? To drag what's best in him out into the street so every average slob with some pretense to taste can poke it with a stick?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You must be pretty impressed with yourself, huh? The all too obviously talented new man, the important new voice, the early clue to a new direction, or whatever, etc., etc., etc! A popular new trend conveniently packaged for the distracted young herd! You want to be liked more than you know, Simon Grim! You'd be nowhere without me and you know it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I saw you for what you were in the beginning, Simon. I hold no grudge and I'm certain you will, in time, leave some serious and small dent in this world.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (weakly) The world is full of shit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The world is full of shit. It's true. And you have to walk through it. That's your part. I'm sorry. But you're no good at it. Perhaps I'm not. Perhaps I wasn't made to walk through shit. Go on now. Leave. Do what you're good at. Go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . THE INFERNO -- DAY Moments later. Henry enters with Ned on his back and the bartender, Patty, goes ballistic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She suddenly becomes all soft and cuddly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He nods and Henry stands him on a stool at the bar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hands Ned a cigarette and lights it for him. Ned takes a drag and coughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ned nods in agreement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And he offers the kid his whiskey.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Henry, what did I tell you about bringing the kid in here!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How you doin', sweetie? You wanna Coke?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So what did you learn at school today, Ned? Anything?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: See. That'll teach ya. Here, sip this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . THE GRIM HOUSE -- DAY Same time. Fay comes out of the house and looks for her son.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . GARAGE -- NIGHT The place is abandoned. Henry comes in and, just as he is laying down to go to sleep on an old couch, finds Pearl age fourteen. She is hardened and disturbed, but frequently vulnerable and scared; a troubled kid.

direction.raw_text: Henry falls back and looks at Vicky. She looks away. Henry looks at Warren, pauses, then gives him a sharp, hard shove. Warren stands back against the wall, pauses, then erupts into viciousness. He grabs Henry and throws him violently down the hall, where he hits the wall and collapses. As Henry gets to his knees, Warren kicks him in the ribs. Henry curls up and rolls out on to the kitchen floor. Warren kicks him in the side of the head. Vicky sits back down on the bed, covering her ears. Warren beats the hell out of Henry, kicking him in the face and ribs whenever he manages to get up on his hands and knees. Henry crawls under the kitchen table for safety. Warren grabs his feet and drags him out. As he is dragged across the floor, Henry finds a screwdriver and grabs it. He rolls over on his back as... Warren lunges down at him again and...

He stands there in the middle of the kitchen, amazed, with the screwdriver sticking out of his chest. Henry, semi-conscious and severely beaten, falls against the back door and coughs up a few of his teeth. Vicky steps into the hall from her room and shudders. Warren sits at the table, stunned. He looks from the screwdriver to Vicky, then...

Laura, the secretary from the publishing house. She is dressed for travel and has her coat hung over her arm, a suitcase in her hand. She smiles at him, then looks from the boy to someone across the room and... Ned follows her gaze to find... Simon, standing there before him, a suitcase in his hand as well.
